titleStmt.title: Gravestone of Molly Preston and Martin Sansome Preston

support.p: This is a stone (possibly limestone) gravestone ( 70 cm 104 cm 11 cm ).

supportDesc.condition: This gravestone is in good condition, with all text visible and legible, and the only problem being dirt.

layoutDesc.layout: The text is carved onto the gravestone and is centred on the gravestone, taking up the entire inscribed field. There is no border, however there is a decorative celtic cross inscribed into the top of the gravestone in the centre, acting as a centrepiece.

handDesc.summary: The text is a largely uniform size, although the largest letters are reserved for that of the name of Molly Preston.

origin.origPlace: Churchyard of Holy Trinity Church, Penn

div.ab:
IN FOND MEMORY OF
MOLLY PRESTON
BELOVED WIFE OF
ARTHUR SANSOME PRESTON
OF CAIRO EGYPT
AND OF THEIR SON
MARTIN SANSOME PRESTON
KILLED HAZEBROUEK 1940
DECEASED 13 FEB 1949.
REST IN PEACE

div.p: Shortened months have been given in their full forms in the 'translation'
In fond memory of Molly Preston, beloved wife of Arthur Sansome Preston of Cairo, Egypt, and of their son Martin Sansome Preston, killed Hazebrouek 1940, deceased 13th February 1949. Rest in peace.

This twentieth century gravestone lists the names of two occupants, Molly Preston and her son, Martin Sansome Preston. The reading of this stone is difficult at first, as one only learns the death date of Molly Preston at the bottom of the stone, after being told of the death date of her son. The inclusion of the husband in this structure also makes it seem as if he is also an occupant in the grave, although this doesn't appear to be the case upon further reading. We are told that Martin Sansome Preston was killed, presumably in battle in the Second World War, in a place called Hazebrouek in 1940. It is likely that he would have died in the French town of Hazebrouck, as this had a frontier in 1940 and Hazebrouek did not. The reason for the difference cannot be certain however, whether this was the name of the town in the Second World War, or whether this is simply an error by the stonemason. While on all of the other gravestone, we have been able to use information on the gravestone to approximate missing values, such as year of birth or age, this gravestone is strange for the reason that only the dates of death are supplied, meaning that neither age nor year of birth can be calculated. The word deceased is an interesting choice, where other gravestones list their occupants as having died or departed, this gravestone seems to take a much more clinical approach to death. This is also the only grave in this collection with the formula 'Rest in peace'.
